summary: I realized one day that so many problems with immersion-breaking in Skyrim can be easily solved by simply: increasing many items weights and values in a very detailed and calculated way.~ So that's what I did with this mod.~
descriptionHtml:
[color=#00FF00][size=50][b][u]Realistic Items' Weights And Values[/u][/b][/size][/color]

[img]http://static-2.nexusmods.com/15/mods/110/images/49312-3-1388530786.jpg[/img]
[url=https://www.pathofexile.com/forum/view-thread/696553]fantasy items shop by Freelong[/url]

Keywords: real, realism, realistic, item, items, number, numbers, balanced, fair, weigh, weight, value, price, cost, immersive, immersion, series, multiple, mod, mods.

[size=4][color=#00FFFF]I realized one day that so many problems with immersion-breaking in Skyrim can be easily solved by simply: increasing many items' weights and values in a very detailed and calculated way.~[/color]

Things this mod DOES NOT CHANGE:

Weapons
Armor (Except Dragonscale & Dragonbone Armor)
Clothing
Jewelery
Backpacks, Pouches, etc.
[color=#00FF00]Potions[/color]
[color=#FFFF00]Food[/color]
[color=#00FFFF]Drinks[/color]
[color=#893BFF]Soul Gems[/color]
Gems (like [color=#800080]Amethysts[/color], [color=#FF0000]Rubies[/color], and [color=#0000FF]Sapphires[/color])
[color=#348017]Alchemy Ingredients[/color]

Enjoy!~[/size]


[color=#00FFFF][size=10]Recommendations:[/size][/color] [size=4]If you want all Races to start out with DIFFERENT MORE 'believable' carrying weights, then use my other mod WITH any of the Realistic Items series for a truly more 'immersive' experience:[/size]

[url=http://www.nexusmods.com/skyrim/mods/48929/?][color=#FFFFFF][size=5]More Believable Carrying Weight[/size][/color][/url]


[color=#FFFF00][size=4]Also for more realistic jumping overall try out my other mod: Athletic Jump increases your ability to jump without being ridiculous and unrealistic.~[/size][/color]

[url=http://www.nexusmods.com/skyrim/mods/49167/?][color=#FFFF00][size=5]Athletic Jump[/size][/color][/url]


[size=4]I also highly recommend you find a great Arrow Weight mod, because to me: carrying over 100 Arrows with NO increase in weight AT ALL is totally bordering on making all Arrows in existence 'magically weightless' story-wise just to make sense of it.~[/size]


[color=#00FFFF][size=4]Lastly, if you like to play as a Werewolf you can try out my biggest mod created with MichaelDusk, called: [u]Werewolves Unleashed[/u]: a newly balanced, progressive Werewolf 'unleashing':[/size][/color]

[url=http://www.nexusmods.com/skyrim/mods/48956/?][color=#00FFFF][size=5]Werewolves Unleashed[/size][/color][/url]


[size=5][color=#00FF00]ALL MODS ARE COMPATIBLE AND WORK WELL TOGETHER!~

If you want to use all of my (and MichaelDusk's) mods together, then place them in this order:[/color]

[color=#FFFF00]Athletic Jump[/color] or [color=#00FFFF]Supernatural Jump[/color]
[color=#00FFFF]Werewolves Unleashed[/color]
[color=#00FF00]Realistic Items' Weights and Values[/color]
More Believable Carrying Weight[/size]



[color=#00FFFF][size=10]Requirements:[/size] [size=4]Skyrim[/size][/color]



[color=#FFFF00][size=10]Compatibility:[/size][/color]

[color=#00FFFF][size=4]This mod is intended to NOT change ANY quest items, nor does it currently change potions, food, nor drinks to be maximumally compatible with other "Immersive Mods".~

Please test these out as you please and please let me and every one else here know if some parts are not compatible with certain mods and how balanced it is.~

Thank you.~[/size][/color]



[size=2][i]Now every one, I present:[/i][/size] [size=5][i]Realistic Items' Weights And Values!~[/i][/size]

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

[color=#FFA500][size=20][u]Realistic Metals, Ores, and Ingots[/u][/size][/color]

[img]http://static-2.nexusmods.com/15/mods/110/images/49312-1-1388530785.jpg[/img]
[url=http://www.abb.com/cawp/seitp202/1a19293a6ee21f30c1257a3e0033a86f.aspx]ABB wins five-year Full Service agreement for copper smelting plant in Namibia[/url]

[color=#FFA500][size=4]Mining using only a pickaxe and one's hands is a long hard task requiring a great amount of strength and time that can take an entire day to even weeks to months to even years to accomplish.~ Some make a career out of it.~


[color=#FFFF00]According to:[/color] [url=http://www.usmint.gov/about_the_mint/fun_facts/?action=fun_facts13]http://www.usmint.gov/about_the_mint/fun_facts/?action=fun_facts13[/url][/size]

[size=4][color=#FFFF00]the measurements of a Gold Bar in The Federal Reserve is 7 inches x 3.625 inches x 1.75 inches

and 1 U.S.A. Mint Gold Bar weighs about 27.5 pounds.[/color][/size]

[size=4][color=#FFFF00]According to this:[/color] [url=http://ocgold.com/blog/?p=18122] http://ocgold.com/blog/?p=18122[/url][/size]

[size=4][color=#FFFF00]Gold Ingots must be at least 95% pure gold to be considered an Ingot while Gold Bars don't have to be this pure to be considered a Gold Bar.

This:[/color] [url=http://www.elmhurst.edu/~chm/vchembook/125Adensitygold.html]http://www.elmhurst.edu/~chm/vchembook/125Adensitygold.html[/url][/size]

[size=4][color=#FFFF00]calculates the weight of a standard U.S.A. Gold Bar in The Federal Reserves as 30 pounds based only on its' dimensions and the Atomic Density of Gold, meaning this is assuming that the Gold Bar being calculated is 100% Pure Gold which would definitely qualify it as a Gold Ingot.

Since this web page also showed me how to calculate this for myself, I checked the math:

Mathematical Definition of Density:

"The formal definition of density is mass per unit volume. Usually the density is expressed in grams per mL or cc.
Mathematically a "per" statement is translated as a division. cc is a cubic centimeter and is equal to a mL Therefore:

Density = mass = g/mL volume"

Which means Grams/Cubic Centimeter x Volume = Weight

g/cc x Volume = Weight

Inches to Centimeters: [url=http://www.metric-conversions.org/length/inches-to-centimeters-table.htm]http://www.metric-conversions.org/length/inches-to-centimeters-table.htm[/url]

[1 inch = 2.54 centimeters]

7 inches x 2.54 centimeters = 17.78cm

3.625 inches x 2.54 centimetes = 9.2075cm

1.75 inches x 2.54 centimeters = 4.445cm

17.78cm x 9.2075cm x 4.445cm = 727.68806075cm

Gold's Atomic Density is 19.282g/cc (Grams per Cubic Centimeter)

19.282g/cc x 727.68806075cm = 1,4031.2811873815g (Grams)

Pounds to Grams:[/color] [url=http://www.metric-conversions.org/weight/pounds-to-grams-table.htm]http://www.metric-conversions.org/weight/pounds-to-grams-table.htm[/url][/size]

[size=4][color=#FFFF00][1 Pound = 453.59 Grams]

1,4031.2811873815g / 453.59g = 30.93384154717145439714279415331lb. = 31lb. (rounded)

Turns out it's actually 31 pounds (rounded).[/color]

[color=#3CB371]Malachite[/color] and Moonstone:

[color=#3CB371]According to:[/color] [url=http://www.classicgems.net/Density.htm]http://www.classicgems.net/Density.htm[/url][/size]

[size=4][color=#3CB371]Malachite[/color] and Moonstone are gems and [color=#3CB371]can vary in density[/color] based upon composition.

[color=#FFA500]Corundum:

According to:[/color] [url=http://www.mindat.org/min-1136.html]http://www.mindat.org/min-1136.html[/url][/size]

[size=4][color=#FFA500]Corundum is a mineral, is actually a combination of elements, and can vary in density based upon composition.[/color]

[color=#2E8B57]Orichalcum:

According to:[/color] [url=http://www.coinandbullionpages.com/gold-alloys/orichalcum.html]http://www.coinandbullionpages.com/gold-alloys/orichalcum.html[/url][/size]

[size=4][color=#2E8B57]Orichalcum is a mysterious metal that is said to shine like Gold at times but is not actually Gold and appears to have properties of Copper as well, thus I decided to go with Copper's weight as copper is lighter than Gold and a magical metal that looks like Gold but is lighter seems reasonable to me.[/color]

[color=#A9A9A9]Steel:

Steel is made by combining[/color] [color=#FFA500]1 Corundum Ingot[/color] [color=#708090]and 1 Iron Ingot.[/color]

[color=#778899]Quicksilver:

Quicksilver is another name for Mercury.[/color]

Ebony:

Ebony has the name of a hard, tough, and heavy wood in Our World, but according The Elder Scrolls lore is described as a volcanic metal that is black and
glass-like making it seem very similar to Obsidian which is actually very lightweight.

Ebony Armor weighs slightly more than Orcish Armor, which is a combination of Orichalcum and [color=#708090]Iron,[/color] thus it is reasonable to say that Ebony is heavier than Orichalcum and [color=#708090]Iron[/color] combined, which is 8.993g/cc + 7.874g/cc = 16.867/cc, rounded that's 16.87g/cc which seems reasonable to me.

[color=#FFA500]Dwarven Metal:

Dwarven Armor is Heavier than[/color] Ebony Armor, [color=#FFA500]but is made of 3 Dwarven Metal Ingots[/color] [color=#708090]+ 1 Iron Ingot[/color] [color=#A9A9A9]+ 1 Steel Ingot,[/color] [color=#FFA500]that's 60% Dwarven Metal and 40%[/color] [color=#708090]Iron[/color][color=#FFA500]/[/color][color=#A9A9A9]Steel.[/color]

[color=#A9A9A9]1 Steel[/color] [color=#FFA500]and[/color] [color=#708090]1 Iron[/color] [color=#FFA500]combined is 7.6lb + 5.2lb = 12.8 pounds although[/color] [color=#708090]Iron[/color][color=#FFA500]/[/color][color=#A9A9A9]Steel[/color] [color=#FFA500]may comprise only 40% of Dwarven Armor, it may also comprise a majority of the weight of the armor. A metal does not have to be heavy to be considered strong and Dwarven Metal is very similar to[/color] [color=#2E8B57]the mysterious Orichalcum in many ways.[/color]

[color=#FFA500]Dwarven Armor weighs 45 pounds - 12.8 pounds = 32.2lb./3i. = 11 pounds (rounded)[/color]

I found all the other Atomic Density Grams per Cubic Centimeters of The Elements here: [url=http://education.jlab.org/itselemental/]http://education.jlab.org/itselemental/[/url][/size]

[size=4]Moonstone Atomic Density per Cubic Centimeter = 2.57g/cc
[color=#3CB371]Malachite Atomic Density per Cubic Centimeter = 3.80g/cc[/color]
[color=#FFA500]Corundum Atomic Density per Cubic Centimeter = 3.997g/cc[/color]
[color=#708090]Iron Atomic Density per Cubic Centimeter = 7.874g/cc[/color]
[color=#FFA500]Copper Atomic Density per Cubic Centimeter = 8.933g/cc[/color]
[color=#696969]Silver Atomic Density per Cubic Centimeter = 10.501g/cc[/color]
[color=#778899]Mercury Atomic Density per Cubic Centimer = 13.5336g/cc[/color]
Ebony Atomic Density per Cubic Centimeter = 16.87g/cc
[color=#FFFF00]Gold Atomic Density per Cubic Centimeter = 19.282g/cc

If I use the same dimensions for a Gold Bar as I do for all the other metals and round all the numbers into whole numbers then I can use this formula:

(728cm x AD) / 454g = Weight of 1 Metal Ingot ; AD = Atomic Density[/color]

Metal Ingots:

Moonstone Ingot = 4 pounds
[color=#3CB371]Malachite Ingot = 6 pounds[/color]
[color=#FFA500]Corundum Ingot = 6 pounds[/color]
[color=#708090]Iron Ingot = 13 pounds[/color]
[color=#2E8B57]Orichalcum Ingot = 14 pounds[/color]
[color=#696969]Silver Ingot = 17 pounds[/color]
[color=#A9A9A9]Steel Ingot = 19 pounds[/color]
[color=#778899]Quicksilver Ingot = 22 pounds[/color]
Ebony Ingot = 27 pounds
[color=#FFFF00]Gold Ingot = 31 pounds[/color]

The Metal Ingot weights are for Pure Metals, but Metal doesn't usually come in a pure state and you must Smelt 2 Ores to get just 1 Ingot of Pure Metal.

I reason that 60% of the Ore, which is probably various types of rock, is smelted away by the Smelting process leaving the Pure 40% Metal, the exception
to this would be Iron Ore as you only need 1 Iron Ore to make 1 Pure Iron Ingot I reason 80% of Iron Ore is Pure Iron while only 20% of the Iron Ore will
be smelted away.

[color=#708090]Iron Ingot: 13 pounds is 80% of Iron Ore, 13 / 0.8 = 16.25 pounds ; Check: 16.25lb. x 0.2 = 3.25lb., 16.25lb. - 3.25lb. = 13 pounds[/color]

For all the other Metals:

Weight of Pure Metal Ingot / 2 = x / 0.4 = 1 Metal Ore

Moonstone Ingot: 4lb. / 2 = 2lb. / 0.4 = 5 pounds; Check: 5lb. x 0.6 = 3lb., 5lb. - 3lb. = 2lb. x 2 = 4 pounds
[color=#3CB371]Malachite Ingot: 6lb. / 2 = 3lb. / 0.4 = 7.5 pounds ; Check: 7.5lb. x 0.6 = 4.5lb., 7.5lb. - 4.5lb. = 3lb. x 2 = 6 pounds[/color]
[color=#FFA500]Corundum Ingot: 6lb. / 2 = 3lb. / 0.4 = 7.5 pounds ; Check: 7.5lb. x 0.6 = 4.5lb., 7.5lb. - 4.5lb. = 3lb. x 2 = 6 pounds[/color]
[color=#2E8B57]Orichalcum Ingot: 14lb. / 2 = 7lb. / 0.4 = 17.5 pounds ; Check: 17.5lb. x 0.6 = 10.5lb., 17.5lb. - 10.5lb. = 7lb. x 2 = 14 pounds[/color]
[color=#696969]Silver Ingot: 17lb. / 2 = 8.5lb. / 0.4 = 21.25 pounds ; Check: 21.25lb x 0.6 = 12.75lb., 21.25lb. - 12.75lb. = 8.5lb. x 2 = 17 pounds[/color]
[color=#778899]Quicksilver Ingot: 22lb. / 2 = 11lb. / 0.4 = 27.5 pounds ; Check: 27.5lb. x 0.6 = 16.5lb., 27.5lb. - 16.5lb. = 11lb. x 2 = 22 pounds[/color]
Ebony Ingot: 27lb. / 2 = 13.5lb. / 0.4 = 33.75 pounds ; Check: 33.75lb. x 0.6 = 20.25lb., 33.75lb. - 20.25lb. = 13.5lb. x 2 = 17 pounds
[color=#FFFF00]Gold Ingot: 31lb. / 2 = 15.5lb. / 0.4 = 38.75 pounds ; Check: 38.75lb x 0.6 = 23.25lb., 38.75lb - 23.25lb. = 15.5lb x 2 = 31 pounds[/color]

Corundum Ore: 7.5 pounds

I went here for The United States Mint Legal Tender Coins Physical Specifications Table: [url=http://www.usmint.gov/about_the_mint/?action=coin_specifications]http://www.usmint.gov/about_the_mint/?action=coin_specifications[/url]

A Knickel seemed like an appropriate medium size coin in size to compare a Gold Septim Coin to so I calculated the Grams to Pounds.

1 U.S.A. Knickel = 5.00 Grams

[1 Pound = 453.59 Grams]

100 Knickels = 500 Grams = 1 Pound (rounded)

[color=#FFFF00]Therefore:

1 Gold Septim Coin = 0.01 pounds

100 Gold Septim Coins = 1 pound[/color]

In order to make the weights of these metals viable for forging armor without changing any thing related to the armors themselves, I've decided to divide all the weights by 2.5, this can easily be explained: I've simply reasoned that the Ingots used in Skyrim are much smaller than the Gold Bars kept in The United States Federal Reserve.

Since Metal Ores are 60% various rock and not Pure Metal I've subtracted 60% off their Values.

Value x 0.6 = x, Value - x = New Value

I also get the same result by dividing by 2.5.

Value / 2.5 = New Value
